Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Genetic and Environmental Mechanisms Mediating Disease Resistance and Tolerance in Amphibians
Award.AbstractNarration:
Identifying the causes of recurrent outbreaks of infectious diseases in the wild is critical to understanding human and ecosystem health. Environmental change may reduce the ability of hosts to evolve resistance or persist within their tolerance limits, thus making pathogens more likely to cause disease and mortality. This project investigates seasonally variable patterns of infection in tropical amphibians and tests the hypotheses that disease patterns are a consequence of changes in the frequency of individuals that have genetically-based resistance to the pathogen, or alternatively, a result of a weakened host condition caused by environmental stress. Frogs lacking genetic determinants may also rely on environmental modulators (e.g., symbiotic bacteria) to alleviate pathogen damage. How and when these immune strategies interact to allow amphibians to persist emergent diseases is unknown. Using declining frog populations in Puerto Rico that exhibit high heterogeneity and seasonality in infection dynamics, the PIs combine population genomics and metagenomics to determine how environmental and host adaptive responses affect the outcome of disease.
The topic of amphibian declines, and its implications for environmental health, has reached public awareness; thus this project offers an excellent opportunity to educate non-scientists about genetics, immunity, and disease ecology. Both PIs disseminate their scientific findings to general audiences through media, educational outreach, and NGOs. In addition, the project involves students and researchers from underrepresented minorities, fosters collaborations between USA and Puerto Rican institutions, and increases diversity among students interested in ecology, evolution, and conservation. These results can be used by conservation agencies in species prioritization schemes and captive breeding programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amphibian biodiversity faces a greater threat from chytrid fungi than from any other group of pathogens. This DDIG project investigated the environmental and genetic factors influencing amphibian responses over time to the amphibian-killing fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd). Currently, Bd infects more than 500 species of amphibians globally, and most of these carry infections that vary over time. Understanding why Bd infections change is a necessary step to predict which species will decline as a consequence of disease. Our work was focused on natural populations of coqui frogs that have been declining in Puerto Rico, yet are persisting with seasonal infections of Bd. Our findings advanced our knowledge about host-pathogen dynamics by: (1) quantifying correlates between fungal infections and microbial diversity in space, time, and individuals in a direct-developing frog; (2) identifying genetic x seasonal interactions involved in infection susceptibility; and (3) confirming that natural fluctuations in environmental conditions shift the survival advantage among the pathogen, the host, and microbial communities. Combined, field surveys and experimental manipulations in the field performed as part of this DDIG project allowed us to identify host traits associated with infection resistance or susceptibility, but also to quantify extrinsic factors, such as the availability of particular skin beneficial bacteria or temperature changes, contributing to tolerance.

Our project benefits society in several ways. First, more than 80% of amphibian species in the Caribbean are classified as threatened or extinct. Therefore, we expect that our findings will improve conservation strategies for many endangered amphibians with similar susceptibilities across the Caribbean. In addition, our findings highlight the impacts of normal periods of cool temperatures and dry conditions to amphibian disease dynamics. An extension or aggravation of these conditions for the rest of the year, such as the severe drought experienced this year, can have detrimental effects for amphibian persistence. Second, our project identifies coqui frogs as a potential source of anti-fungal bacteria that could be used for bioprospecting. Thus, our findings contribute new data to increase our knowledge about the distribution and persistence of bacteria across time and habitats, as well as their putative function in the ecosystem. Finally, our project provided research opportunities and training for underrepresented minorities and women in STEM.
